bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Frederick F. Russell, January 31, 1924

div1.p: Noguchi discusses his leptospira work in Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Frederick F. Russell, January 31, 1924
div1.opener:
COPY.
Bahia,
January 31, 1924.
My dear Colonel Russell:-
div1.p:
I ought to have written you before this, but I knew you were
abroad and I have waited also until I had something worth while writing.
Leaving the minor details for personal reports to be made on my return
I have this much to say: We reached Bahia, via Rio, on November 29,
last year and were comfortably located in a rented house where Dr. White
is also staying. Thanks to the effective cooperation of Dr. Strode;s of-
fice through Dr. Janney, and Dr. Scannell who preceded us by two months
in Bahia, a practically new laboratory called “Oswaldo Cruz Institute of
Bahia” was placed at our disposal at once. The director, Dr. Augusto Vianna,
came over to our house and handed over the whole building. We found the
plans of the laboratory unsurpassed and that by equipping up with our ma-
terial it would make an excellent place for any kind of research work.
It took nearly two weeks to do this, but we soon commenced to start.
Since our arrival there has not been a single case of yellow fever and no
Stegomyia either. Thus, we decided to make the Pfeiffer reaction with
the convalescents' serums from cases that occurred during the year of 1923
--and there were 156 cases in all. We soon found that to obtain serums for
the Pfeiffer tests we had to reach the patients through their physicians.
This necessitated the cooperation of some Brazilian physicians and we en-
gaged a few young University Professors to work with us. We finally got
nine serums from convalescents and four normal serums. The tests were made
with several strains of Leptospira icteroides on one hand and Leptospira
icterohemorrhagica on the other, in parallel series at the same time. It
Colonel Russell -
- Page 2 -
was previously announced so as to invite the entire faculty of the Medi-
cal School here to see the tests actually carried out. After showing the
technique I requested the Brazilian bacteriologists and pathologists to per-
form the tests themselves and this was done. Muller worked with them.
The results were clear out. All the convalescents' serums gave a positive
and the normal a negative Pfeiffer. On the other hand, Letospira ictero-
hemorrhagiae remained absolutely unaffected either by the convalescents' or
normal human serums. This occurred on December 20th and ever since we are
having a whole hearted cooperation of the medical profession of Bahia in
search of yellow fever cases. The bitterest of “icteroides” opponents--
of whom there were many in Bahia and Brazil in general--frankly came to
accept the fact. They also came to realize why Borges-Vieira and a few
others failed--they saw the difference in technic and even the handling of
the dark field microscope. In fact, there were three dark field microscopes
in Bahia, but none was fitted up so as to see Leptospira icteroides. I made
one out of the different parts from these three microscopes, then it worked.
In addition we brought with us two darkfields and used all three for the de-
monstration on that day. Our own animals came in good conditions and this
was another factor contributing to the useful results. I can understand
why they have been so unsuccessful in their attempts along this line of work.
It cannot be done unless properly equipped and thoroughly trained.

The second episode occurred on January 4 this year. Dr. Godofredo
Vianna and Dr. Mario Biao, two selected yellow fever experts belonging to the
Prophylaxia Rural Nacional (a Federal branch at Bahia) went into the interior
at the urgent request of the Mayor of Lençoes, some hundred miles away from
Bahia, to combat the yellow fever situation in a near-by town (3000 Population)
called Palmeiras. They went there in the middle of December and took with
them culture media tubes to make culture from yellow fever patients. One of
Colonel Russell -
- Page 3. -
the men (Dr. Vianna) came back on January 4 with the tubes inoculated with
the blood from five typical cases. These tubes were at once examined by the
members of the Oswaldo Cruz Institute staff. That day Leptospira was found
in one of the tubes (30 in number). A few days later another tube showed
the leptospira. The first positive culture came from a case in which blood
was drawn on the 1st day of the disease and the second positive one from
another in which blood was taken on the 2nd day of illness. Thus two out
of five cases studied Leptospira was isolated. In fact, if contaminations
had not occurred in so many tubes we might have had more strains. Animals
were subsequently inoculated with these two strains and some of them came
down with typical symptoms and lesions. The convalescents' serums from Ba-
hia cases gave a clear positive Pfeiffer reaction with both strains from Pal-
meiras. I am now awaiting the return of the other man, who will bring back
the convalescents' serums from Palmeiras cases to test the other as well as
the Palmeiras strains of L. icteroides. This will complete, for the time
being at least, our immediate work in Bahia. Chagas has been wiring me at
frequent intervals telling me of his intention to come up and I hope he will
make the trip before we get away from Bahia. The failures of the Brazilian
workers previous to our expedition were solely due to inadequate preparations
to undertake this kind of work. They used full grown native guinea pigs and
in small numbers at that. Their culture media were untested before use for
their suitability and they always omit any reference as to the number of cul-
ture tubes used or how many of them remained uncontaminated. No leptospira
will grow where another organism is growing--they will quickly disappear even
if they started to grow as soon as a mould gets in. And you must know how
difficult it is to keep out moulds in tropics! I am wasting so many culture
tubes here only through this uncontrollable fungus invasion through every
kind of stopper. These things are not well understood by most people. Why
Colonel Russell -
- Page 4. -
every man who fails to obtain a positive transmission or a culture of L.
icteroides feels it his duty to conclude that there was no leptospira be-
cause he did not find it or isolate it, is a matter hard to understand.
Lebredos negative results in Merida in 1919 have been keenly read here and
taken as a grave indictment for L. icteroides. But, he had no darkfield to
see a leptospira even taken from a rich culture and placed under it. He
used old Havana guinea pigs for transmission and all his cultures were con-
taminated either with a bacterium or a mould--I saw them in his own labor-
atory in 1919 just after his expedition to Merida. I came to Brazil partly
because I wanted to show them the possible sources of failure and how to
get a positive result. I believe I succeeded in both.

In Recife there has been rumors that there have been some cases
of yellow fever not officially reported. Through Dr. Walcott we sent up two
batches of culture media for obtaining cultures. Altogether four cases were
studied by this way, every one of the tubes sent back by him was found con-
taminated with all kinds of microorganisms from cocci down to moulds. We are
planning to go up there some time in February and, if there are some cases,
to study them there. From there we will go to Fortaleza and get some reliable
statistics regarding the use of the vaccine and serum during the epidemic of
1922-1923. From there to Pará and then back to New York by the Booth Line.
Probably we will be back about the middle of March. During my stay here I
have been giving some practical instructions to some of the young Brazilian
physicians connected with the Medical Faculty and Department of Health and this
has been mutually beneficial in so far as to know each other more intimately.
It is one thing to read one's published articles and another to watch him in
his actual working at a close range. Some of them are very promising. Dr. Wells
can do much for developing good men, I think. There is altogether too little
American medical influence here and that should not be.

I meant to be brief, but after a few words many more followed,
so you have more than you want to read.

I hope you have had a pleasant and interesting trip to Europe and
that you are well as usual.

Muller is one splendid man and has been a great strength and com-
fort to me all through these days.
With kindest regards and best wishes, I am
div1.closer: Yours sincerely Sgd. Hideyo Noguchi. Give my regards to Dr. Rose, please.
